elements.content: A zeolite-like metal−organic framework (ZMOF) has been successfully constructed by using a flexible ligand, 2-(1H-benzimidazol-2-ylthio)acetic acid (H2 L). Under different conditions, four new compounds, [Zn2(HL)4]·(DMF)2·(H2O)2 (1), [Zn2(HL)4] n (2), [Cu(HL)2] n (3), and [Co(L)] n (4), have been synthesized and characterized with this ligand. Complex 1 exhibits a binuclear macrocyclic structure, while 2 is a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) amphiphilic layer further forming a 3D network via van der Waals interactions between the hydrophobic sides and C−H···O interactions between hydrophilic sides. In 3, the 2D (4,4) layers are linked by C−H···C interaction to form a three-dimensional framework, and complex 4 shows a zeolite sodalite (SOD) topology, which represents the first ZMOF from flexible ligands. The fluorescent emissions of 1 and 2, and the magnetic properties of 4 have also been studied.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much interest due to their various potential applications such as separations and catalysis, gas storage, magnetism, and their topological features. As a prominent subset of MOFs, zeolite-like metal−organic frameworks (ZMOFs) which have a topology of inorganic zeolite have witnessed flourishing development in recent years. To construct such materials, besides the directional tetrahedral building units (TBU), the judicious selection of bridging ligands is another factor to be taken into account by researchers. For example, a series of zeolite imidazole frameworks have been designed and synthesized from MII (CoII or ZnII ions) and imidazole derivatives. Recently, some novel ZMOFs have been developed from MN4O4 or MN4O2 and rigid organic acid containing N-donors. Interestingly, almost all of the bent angles of M−L−M in these ZMOFs fall in the range of 140−150° (≈145°).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received much interest due to their various potential applications such as separations and catalysis, gas storage, magnetism, and their topological features. As a prominent subset of MOFs, zeolite-like metal-organic frameworks (ZMOFs) which have a topology of inorganic zeolite have witnessed flourishing development in recent years. To construct such materials, besides the directional tetrahedral building units (TBU), the judicious selection of bridging ligands is another factor to be taken into account by researchers. For example, a series of zeolite imidazole frameworks have been designed and synthesized from MII (CoII or ZnII ions) and imidazole derivatives. Recently, some novel ZMOFs have been developed from MN4O4 or MN4O2 and rigid organic acid containing N-donors. Interestingly, almost all of the bent angles of M-L-M in these ZMOFs fall in the range of 140-150° (~145°).

elements.content: Because of their numerous conformations and coordination modes observed in the coordination process, flexible ligands have been extensively explored in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering, but they have not been reported as building blocks to construct ZMOFs yet, probably because of the difficulty of structural prediction. In this contribution, we choose a new flexible ligand 2-(1H-benzimidazol-2-ylthio)acetic acid (H2 L) which contains both carboxylate and imidazole groups, as a bridging ligand to synthesize ZMOFs, due to the following considerations: (1) imidazole groups may result in a similar bent angle of M−L−M as in the reported literature, which facilitates ZMOFs; (2) chelating dentate of this ligand may result in a seven-membered ring and a larger N−M−O angle (∼110°, in contrast to ∼90° for 5-membered ring), which is useful for tetrahedral coordination geometry and is especially important to metal ions with tetra-, penta-, and hexa-coordination; (3) the syn-anti mode of COO− group may generate a bent angle similar to that of imidazole group.
elements.clean_text: Because of their numerous conformations and coordination modes observed in the coordination process, flexible ligands have been extensively explored in coordination chemistry and crystal engineering, but they have not been reported as building blocks to construct ZMOFs yet, probably because of the difficulty of structural prediction. In this contribution, we choose a new flexible ligand 2-(1H-benzimidazol-2-ylthio)acetic acid (H2 L) which contains both carboxylate and imidazole groups, as a bridging ligand to synthesize ZMOFs, due to the following considerations: (1) imidazole groups may result in a similar bent angle of M-L-M as in the reported literature, which facilitates ZMOFs; (2) chelating dentate of this ligand may result in a seven-membered ring and a larger N-M-O angle (~110°, in contrast to ~90° for 5-membered ring), which is useful for tetrahedral coordination geometry and is especially important to metal ions with tetra-, penta-, and hexa-coordination; (3) the syn-anti mode of COO- group may generate a bent angle similar to that of imidazole group.

elements.content: Herein, we report four new complexes, [Zn2(HL)4]·(DMF)2·(H2O)2 (1), [Zn2(HL)4] n (2), [Cu(HL)2] n (3), and [Co(L)] n (4), from H2 L under different conditions, in which the H2 L ligand exhibits different coordination modes. 1 is a dinuclear macrocycle, while both [Zn2(HL)4] n (2) and [Cu(HL)2] n (3) are two-dimensional (2D) coordination architectures to form three-dimensional (3D) superamolecular networks via weak interactions. [Co(L)] n (4) is a 3D network with sodalite (SOD) topology, which represents the first example of ZMOFs constructed from a flexible ligand. Magnetic susceptibility of 4 suggests dominant antiferromagnetic couplings between adjacent CoII ions.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report four new complexes, [Zn2(HL)4]⋅(DMF)2⋅(H2O)2 (1), [Zn2(HL)4] n  (2), [Cu(HL)2] n  (3), and [Co(L)] n  (4), from H2 L under different conditions, in which the H2 L ligand exhibits different coordination modes. 1 is a dinuclear macrocycle, while both [Zn2(HL)4] n  (2) and [Cu(HL)2] n  (3) are two-dimensional (2D) coordination architectures to form three-dimensional (3D) superamolecular networks via weak interactions. [Co(L)] n  (4) is a 3D network with sodalite (SOD) topology, which represents the first example of ZMOFs constructed from a flexible ligand. Magnetic susceptibility of 4 suggests dominant antiferromagnetic couplings between adjacent CoII ions.

elements.content: H2 L was synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents employed were commercially available and used as received. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Simulations of the XRPD spectra were carried out by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury (Hg) program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org. Emission spectra in the solid state at room temperature were taken on a Cary Eclips fluorescence spectrophotometer. Magnetic data were collected using crushed crystals of the sample on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer, which were corrected using Pascal’s constants to calculate the diamagnetic susceptibility. The complexes were first soaked in ethanol and then heated in a sample tube under a vacuum at a temperature of 100 °C until the pressure in the manifold reached 3 μmHg and was kept at that pressure and temperature for at least 5 h. Samples were transferred between manifolds in sample tubes sealed with Transeals. Hydrogen and nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M and 99.999% pure N2 and H2.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

H2 L was synthesized according to the literature method. All other reagents employed were commercially available and used as received. IR spectra were measured on a Tensor 27 OPUS (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Simulations of the XRPD spectra were carried out by the single-crystal data and diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury (Hg) program available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org. Emission spectra in the solid state at room temperature were taken on a Cary Eclips fluorescence spectrophotometer. Magnetic data were collected using crushed crystals of the sample on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer, which were corrected using Pascal's constants to calculate the diamagnetic susceptibility. The complexes were first soaked in ethanol and then heated in a sample tube under a vacuum at a temperature of 100 °C until the pressure in the manifold reached 3 μmHg and was kept at that pressure and temperature for at least 5 h. Samples were transferred between manifolds in sample tubes sealed with Transeals. Hydrogen and nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M and 99.999% pure N2 and H2.

elements.content: H2 L (0.1 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (5 mL) was added to a methanol solution (5 mL) containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The resulted clear colorless solution was filtrated and sealed in a closed vessel. Left undisturbed and then colorless block-shaped crystals were harvested two weeks later. Yield: ∼50% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C42H46Zn2N10O12S4: C, 44.17; H, 4.06; N, 12.27. Found: C, 44.41; H, 3.61; N, 12.54%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450s, 2169w, 1645vs, 1498w, 1399vs, 1299w, 1274m, 1223s, 1148m, 761m, 749w, 731w.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Complexes 1-4 

[Zn2(HL)4]⋅(DMF)2⋅(H2O)2 (1)

H2 L (0.1 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (5 mL) was added to a methanol solution (5 mL) containing Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The resulted clear colorless solution was filtrated and sealed in a closed vessel. Left undisturbed and then colorless block-shaped crystals were harvested two weeks later. Yield: ~50% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C42H46Zn2N10O12S4: C, 44.17; H, 4.06; N, 12.27. Found: C, 44.41; H, 3.61; N, 12.54%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3450s, 2169w, 1645vs, 1498w, 1399vs, 1299w, 1274m, 1223s, 1148m, 761m, 749w, 731w.

elements.content: A buffer layer of a solution of methanol and distilled water (V:V = 1:1, 12 mL) was carefully layered over a distilled water (2 mL) solution of H2 L ligand (0.1 mmol) which was added triethylamine to adjust the pH to about 7. Then, a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was layered over the buffer layer. After being left undisturbed under room temperature, pure colorless crystals were harvested after three weeks. Yield: ∼30% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C36H28Zn2N8O8S4: C, 45.05; H, 2.94; N, 11.68. Found: C, 45.46; H, 2.67; N, 11.91%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445vs, 1581m, 1502vs, 1415s, 1375vs, 1301m, 1280w, 1225s, 1140s, 1015m, 995w, 731vs, 712m, 595m.

elements.content: 4 was solvothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of H2 L (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) in a aqueous ethanol (V:V = 1:1) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated to 120 °C for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature over 12 h. Black−purple crystals were collected and washed sequentially by water and ethanol. Yield: ∼50% (based on H2 L)). Anal. Calcd. for C54H36Co6N12O12S6: C, 40.76; H, 2.28; N, 10.56. Found: C, 41.02; H, 2.49; N, 10.71%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 2360s, 2341m, 1565s, 1459s, 1434m, 1389vs, 1276s, 1234m, 1151s, 715vs, 733m, 653w.

elements.content:
Caution! Although we have met no problems in handling azide and azido-metal complexes during this work, they should be treated with great caution owing to their potential explosive nature.

Crystal Structure Determination

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1−4 were collected on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer at 293(2) K. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengthes and angles are listed in .

elements.content: H2 L ligand possesses both carboxylate and imidazole groups, and may display several different coordination modes depending on reaction conditions (Chart ). However, only the mode V may facilitate the formation of ZMOF with tetrahedral building units. Thus, H2 L and MII (M = Zn, Cu, and Co) were chosen as starting materials. First, ZnII salt directly reacted with H2 L at conventional conditions without adjusting the pH value, and complex 1 was obtained in which the hydrogen atom in N−H of the imidazole group had not been deprotoned. After the reaction pH value was adjusted to about 7 by triethylamine, 2 and 3 (ZnII and CuII salts as metal sources) were formed by layer diffusion, in which only one nitrogen atom of imidazole group was coordinated to MII ions, with similar conformation adopted in the two complexes. Therefore, a solvothermal method was employed. Originally, NaOH and triethylamine were used as a base to synthesize complex 4, but only poor crystals unsuitable for SCXRD were harvested. Thus, azide was employed to adjusting the pH value of the reaction under similar reaction conditions, and complex 4 was successfully harvested with the expectation of all coordination sites occupied, showing SOD topology.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

H2 L ligand possesses both carboxylate and imidazole groups, and may display several different coordination modes depending on reaction conditions (Chart ). However, only the mode V may facilitate the formation of ZMOF with tetrahedral building units. Thus, H2 L and MII (M = Zn, Cu, and Co) were chosen as starting materials. First, ZnII salt directly reacted with H2 L at conventional conditions without adjusting the pH value, and complex 1 was obtained in which the hydrogen atom in N-H of the imidazole group had not been deprotoned. After the reaction pH value was adjusted to about 7 by triethylamine, 2 and 3 (ZnII and CuII salts as metal sources) were formed by layer diffusion, in which only one nitrogen atom of imidazole group was coordinated to MII ions, with similar conformation adopted in the two complexes. Therefore, a solvothermal method was employed. Originally, NaOH and triethylamine were used as a base to synthesize complex 4, but only poor crystals unsuitable for SCXRD were harvested. Thus, azide was employed to adjusting the pH value of the reaction under similar reaction conditions, and complex 4 was successfully harvested with the expectation of all coordination sites occupied, showing SOD topology.

elements.clean_text: 1  The Structure and Coordination Modes of H2 L

elements.content: Complex 1 is a dinuclear structure, in which the Zn1 ion adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry (Figure a), which is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (Zn1−N1 = 2.027(6), Zn1−N3 = 2.019(6) Å, Table ) and two oxygen atoms (Zn1−O1A = 1.931(5), Zn1−O3 = 1.954(6) Å) from two different ligands. In 1, the ligands take two different coordination modes: I and II (Chart ). Two HL − in mode I bridge two ZnII to form a 14-membered macrocycle, while the remnant two sites of each ZnII center are occupied by another two HL − in mode II, with the intramolecular Zn···Zn distance being ca. 7.5 Å (Figure a). Notably, all the atoms in the macrocycle consisting of the two HL − in mode I and the two ZnII ions site almost locate at the same plane, with the coplanarity deviation of 13.66°. Moreover, double N−H···O hydrogen bonds (2.990 and 3.046 Å, Table S2 in ) in 1 further connect the macrocycle molecules with the four neighboring ones to construct a 2D supramolecular network (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of the Complexes

[Zn2(HL)4]⋅(DMF)2⋅(H2O)2 (1)

Complex 1 is a dinuclear structure, in which the Zn1 ion adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry (Figure a), which is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms (Zn1-N1 = 2.027(6), Zn1-N3 = 2.019(6) Å, Table ) and two oxygen atoms (Zn1-O1A = 1.931(5), Zn1-O3 = 1.954(6) Å) from two different ligands. In 1, the ligands take two different coordination modes: I and II (Chart ). Two HL - in mode I bridge two ZnII to form a 14-membered macrocycle, while the remnant two sites of each ZnII center are occupied by another two HL - in mode II, with the intramolecular Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance being ca. 7.5 Å (Figure a). Notably, all the atoms in the macrocycle consisting of the two HL - in mode I and the two ZnII ions site almost locate at the same plane, with the coplanarity deviation of 13.66°. Moreover, double N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (2.990 and 3.046 Å, Table S2 in ) in 1 further connect the macrocycle molecules with the four neighboring ones to construct a 2D supramolecular network (Figure b).

elements.content: In contrast to the metallocyclic motif in 1, the asymmetric structural unit of compound 2 consists of two crystallographically independent ZnII ions, four HL − ligands. Zn1 ion is tetrahedrallly surrounded by two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from four independent HL − ligands, and Zn2 ion has a coordination geometry similar to that of Zn1 (Figure a). The bond distances around Zn1 and Zn2 range from 1.976(6) to 2.017(8) Å and 1.970(7) to 2.003(8) Å, respectively, which are in the normal range. The angle centered Zn1 and Zn2 ions fall in the range of 99.1(3)−120.9(3)° and 98.7(3)−120.4(3)°, respectively, which indicates that the tetrahedral geometries around ZnII ions are slightly distorted. All the HL − groups act as mode III to bridge two ZnII ions (Chart ), which constructs a 2D (4,4) grid in the ab plane, with the adjacent intralayer Zn···Zn distances ranging from 7.683 to 7.709 Å (Figure b). Interestingly, all the benzimidazolyl rings of the HL − ligands are distributed at the same side of the 2D layer to form a hydrophobic side, while the carboxylate groups are arranged at the other side to build a hydrophilic side. Therefore, the 2D structure of 2 is an amphiphilic sheet, in which the hydrophilic side is further linked to the hydrophilic side of the adjacent layer via C−H···O (hydrophilic side) and the hydrophobic side is linked to the hydrophobic side of another adjacent layer via van der Waals interactions (Figure c).

elements.content: The CuII ion in 3 is located in the symmetrical inversion center, and its coordination sphere consists of two nitrogen atoms (N2D and N2B, with Cu1−N2B = 1.980(3) Å) and four oxygen atoms (O2A, O2C, O1A, and O1C, with Cu1−O2A = 1.981(2) and Cu1−O1A = 2.645 Å), to complete an elongated octahedron because of the Jahn−Teller effect (Figure a). In contrast to 2, the coordination mode of the HL − in 3 acts as mode IV to bridge two CuII ions (Chart ). Each HL − group bridges two CuII ions to construct a 2D (4,4) grid (Figure b), with the shortest intralayer Cu···Cu distance of 7.664 Å, which is further extended to a 3D supramolecular network via C−H···C interactions (Figure c).

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, the CoII ion in 4 has slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry which is comprised of two oxygen atoms O1B and O2A (Co1−O1B = 1.981(4), Co1−O2A = 1.958(5) Å) and two nitrogen atoms N1 and N2A (Co1−N1 = 1.990(5), Co1−N2A = 1.980(5) Å) from three different L 2− groups (Figure a). The O(N)−Co−O(N) angles fall in the range of 101.4−114.9° (especially, the N2A−Co1−O2A = 113.3°), with a small deviation to standard tetrahedron. Significantly, the flexible carboxylate ligand adopts mode V (Chart ) to bridge three CoII ions, which is consistent with what we expected. The shortest Co···Co distances separated by COO− and imidazole groups in the network are 4.99 and 6.05 Å, respectively. And the bent angles for COO− (syn-anti) and imidazoyl groups to bridge two cobalt ions are 124.3° and 150.3°, respectively; the former is slightly different from that of reported angles in a ZMOF.

elements.content: In 4, the L 2− groups connect three cobalt ions to build 3D frameworks (Figure b). Because of the flexible −SCH2COO− group, a better insight into the structure of 4 is only treating the CoII ions as a four-connected node, regardless of the “Y” shape of L 2− groups. The imidazole groups joined cobalt ions to form a one-dimensional (1D) 3-fold helical chain, which is connected to three adjacent helixes with opposite chirality by syn-anti COO− groups and built into sodalite (SOD) topology (Figure c). Notably, compound 4 is the first ZMOF constructed from flexible ligands. In 4, the square tilings of sodalite network consist of Co4(COO)2(imidazole)2, in which two COO− and two imidazole groups are arranged in alternating modes (Figure b). However, there are two types of hexagonal tilings in the network, two Co6(COO)6 rings in “chair” conformation and six Co6(COO)2(imidazole)4 ones with coplanarity. These distorted Co6(COO)6 rings resulted from the bent angles 124.3° of COO− groups, almost 20° smaller than ideal bent angles of zeolites (). Four Co4(COO)2(imidazole)2, two Co6(COO)6, and six Co6(COO)2(imidazole)4 tilings share their edges to enclose into a distorted truncated octahedral cage of a sodalite network. The distortion of cages can be mainly attributed to the different distances of CoII···CoII ions and bent angles of bridging groups. These cages are further built into a 3D framework by sharing its tilings (Figure c, ). Platon calculations reveal that the potential solvent accessible void volume in 4 is about 348 Å3 per unit cell (7.3% of the cell volume). The benzimidazole groups stretch into the cavities resulting in small hexagonal apertures, with a pore size of about 2.4 Å3 ().

elements.content: The imidazole ring and the flexible carboxylate group of the H2 L can act as either bidentate or multidentate ligands when coordinating to metal ions under different conditions, and five coordination modes for H2 L have been observed in these complexes. In complex 1, there are two kinds of ligand conformations existing (Figure a) in the asymmetric unit, which are denoted as I and II, respectively. I adopts a bidentate chelating mode, while II adopts a μ2-O,N stretching mode. The conformation denotation in complexes 2−4 are III, IV, and V.
elements.clean_text:
Conformation of Ligand H2 L 

The imidazole ring and the flexible carboxylate group of the H2 L can act as either bidentate or multidentate ligands when coordinating to metal ions under different conditions, and five coordination modes for H2 L have been observed in these complexes. In complex 1, there are two kinds of ligand conformations existing (Figure a) in the asymmetric unit, which are denoted as I and II, respectively. I adopts a bidentate chelating mode, while II adopts a μ2-O,N stretching mode. The conformation denotation in complexes 2-4 are III, IV, and V.

elements.content: A structural comparison of I−V shows the influence of conformation adopted by H2 L on the final frameworks. Apparently, catering to the coordination geometry of the metal ions and the pH value of the reaction system, H2 L adopts different conformations via stretching, bending, and rotating the flexible carboxylate arms. A perspective of superimposed images of the H2 L corresponding to the complexes 1−4 will is drawn (Figure S3 in ). Each of these H2 L ligands adopts diverse conformations according to the requirement of framework formation. II can be identified easily (yellow) because of its stretching mode of the flexible arm. III and IV (blue and rose) are almost identical for the isostructural frameworks of 2 and 3. The conformation variations can be quantified by parameters: (a) the S−C angular deviations from the nitrogen atoms of imidazoly group, θ . (b) the tortion angle between the −S−CH2C− group and the benzimidazolyl ring, φ . The θ and φ are bigger for the bidentate chelating coordination mode. On the contrary, conformations with smaller φ tend to adopt a stretching mode as in II (Table ).

Complexes 1−4 are based on the same ligand, but their structures are quite different. In complexes 1, 2, and 4, the metal ions take tetrahedral coordination geometry, while in 3, the CuII ions take an elongated octahedral coordination geometry. Complexes 1 and 2 synthesized under different conditions, share the same ligand and metal ion (ZnII), but their structures and the coordination modes of the ligand are quite different. This suggests the influence of reaction conditions on the resulting structures. Complexes 2 and 3 synthesized under the same conditions except for different metal ions adopted exhibit distinguishing coordination modes. This may be ascribed to a diverse metal coordination habit. Complexes 3 and 4 also share the same ligand but differ in metal ions, and the conditions for preparing them are also different. Therefore, the difference in the structure of the two complexes is due to the influences of the nature of the metal ions as well as synthetic conditions.

Comparison of Complexes Structures

Complexes 1-4 are based on the same ligand, but their structures are quite different. In complexes 1, 2, and 4, the metal ions take tetrahedral coordination geometry, while in 3, the CuII ions take an elongated octahedral coordination geometry. Complexes 1 and 2 synthesized under different conditions, share the same ligand and metal ion (ZnII), but their structures and the coordination modes of the ligand are quite different. This suggests the influence of reaction conditions on the resulting structures. Complexes 2 and 3 synthesized under the same conditions except for different metal ions adopted exhibit distinguishing coordination modes. This may be ascribed to a diverse metal coordination habit. Complexes 3 and 4 also share the same ligand but differ in metal ions, and the conditions for preparing them are also different. Therefore, the difference in the structure of the two complexes is due to the influences of the nature of the metal ions as well as synthetic conditions.

elements.content: The photoluminescent spectra of H2 L, complexes 1 and 2 were studied in the solid state at room temperature whose purities were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements (), and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure . For complexes 1 and 2, there are strong emission peaks at 392 and 391 nm excited at 287 nm. These emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), but they may be assigned to intraligand (n−π* or π−π*) emissions because similar emissions are observed at 391 nm for the free ligand H2 L. It is clear that in comparison with the ligand, the ZnII complexes show obvious enhancement of emission relative intensity, and this is probably due to ligation of the ligand to the d10 metal center. To some extent, the coordination enhances the “rigidity” of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Emissions

The photoluminescent spectra of H2 L, complexes 1 and 2 were studied in the solid state at room temperature whose purities were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements (), and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure . For complexes 1 and 2, there are strong emission peaks at 392 and 391 nm excited at 287 nm. These emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), but they may be assigned to intraligand (n-π* or π-π*) emissions because similar emissions are observed at 391 nm for the free ligand H2 L. It is clear that in comparison with the ligand, the ZnII complexes show obvious enhancement of emission relative intensity, and this is probably due to ligation of the ligand to the d10 metal center. To some extent, the coordination enhances the "rigidity" of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility of 4 was measured in the temperature range 2−300 K on polycrystalline samples whose phase purity was confirmed by PXRD pattern (), at the magnetic field of 1 KOe, and the magnetic behavior is shown in Figure as plots of χM T versus T and 1/χM versus T, where χM is the magnetic susceptibility per CoII ion. For 4, the χm T value of 2.79 cm3 mol−1 K at 300 K is much greater than the value (1.88 cm3 mol−1 K) of one isolated metal centers of CoII with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0, which is attributed to spin−orbital couplings. As the temperature cools down, the χM T product continuously decreases to a value of 0.078 cm3 K mol−1 at 2 K, close to diamagnetic state, which indicates dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the CoII ions in 4. The high-temperature data (above 50 K) follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Curie constant C = 3.05 cm3 K mol−1 and negative Weiss constant θ = −34.49 K, in agreement with the overall antiferromagnetic interactions in the 3D network of 4 which is usually common in imidazole and syn-anti COO− bridges.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibility of 4 was measured in the temperature range 2-300 K on polycrystalline samples whose phase purity was confirmed by PXRD pattern (), at the magnetic field of 1 KOe, and the magnetic behavior is shown in Figure  as plots of χM T versus T and 1/χM versus T, where χM is the magnetic susceptibility per CoII ion. For 4, the χm T value of 2.79 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is much greater than the value (1.88 cm3 mol-1 K) of one isolated metal centers of CoII with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0, which is attributed to spin-orbital couplings. As the temperature cools down, the χM T product continuously decreases to a value of 0.078 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K, close to diamagnetic state, which indicates dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the CoII ions in 4. The high-temperature data (above 50 K) follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Curie constant C = 3.05 cm3 K mol-1 and negative Weiss constant θ = -34.49 K, in agreement with the overall antiferromagnetic interactions in the 3D network of 4 which is usually common in imidazole and syn-anti COO- bridges.

elements.content: In the course of construction of ZMOFs by the flexible ligand 2-(1H-benzimidazol-2-ylthio)acetic acid, four new coordination compounds, [Zn2(HL)4]·(DMF)2·(H2O)2 (1), [Zn2(HL)4] n (2), [Cu(HL)2] n (3), and [Co(L)] n (4), have been successfully synthesized, in which diverse coordination modes and conformations were observed for this ligand. Furthermore, complex 4 shows sodalite topology which is a ZMOF paradigm associated with a flexible ligand. This strategy has opened the gate to the construction of ZMOFs through flexible ligands that is still vacant, and the investigations on this type of ligands to assemble ZMOFs with larger pores are underway in our lab.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the course of construction of ZMOFs by the flexible ligand 2-(1H-benzimidazol-2-ylthio)acetic acid, four new coordination compounds, [Zn2(HL)4]⋅(DMF)2⋅(H2O)2 (1), [Zn2(HL)4] n  (2), [Cu(HL)2] n  (3), and [Co(L)] n  (4), have been successfully synthesized, in which diverse coordination modes and conformations were observed for this ligand. Furthermore, complex 4 shows sodalite topology which is a ZMOF paradigm associated with a flexible ligand. This strategy has opened the gate to the construction of ZMOFs through flexible ligands that is still vacant, and the investigations on this type of ligands to assemble ZMOFs with larger pores are underway in our lab.

cln_elements.content:
H2 L (0.1 mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (5 mL) was added to a methanol solution (5 mL) containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The resulted clear colorless solution was filtrated and sealed in a closed vessel. Left undisturbed and then colorless block-shaped crystals were harvested two weeks later. Yield: ∼50% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C42H46Zn2N10O12S4: C, 44.17; H, 4.06; N, 12.27. Found: C, 44.41; H, 3.61; N, 12.54%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3450s, 2169w, 1645vs, 1498w, 1399vs, 1299w, 1274m, 1223s, 1148m, 761m, 749w, 731w.

[Zn<sub>2</sub>(HL)<sub>4</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A buffer layer of a solution of methanol and distilled water (V:V = 1:1, 12 mL) was carefully layered over a distilled water (2 mL) solution of H2 L ligand (0.1 mmol) which was added triethylamine to adjust the pH to about 7. Then, a solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol) in methanol (2 mL) was layered over the buffer layer. After being left undisturbed under room temperature, pure colorless crystals were harvested after three weeks. Yield: ∼30% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C36H28Zn2N8O8S4: C, 45.05; H, 2.94; N, 11.68. Found: C, 45.46; H, 2.67; N, 11.91%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3445vs, 1581m, 1502vs, 1415s, 1375vs, 1301m, 1280w, 1225s, 1140s, 1015m, 995w, 731vs, 712m, 595m.

[Cu(HL)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A procedure similar to that for 2 was followed to prepare 3, except that Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was replaced by Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.1 mmol). Pure blue block-shaped crystals were harvested after four weeks. Yield: ∼35% (based on H2 L). Anal. Calcd. for C18H14CuN4O4S2: C, 45.23; H, 2.95; N, 11.72. Found: C, 45.67; H, 2.54; N, 11.42%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3447s, 2360vs, 2341 m, 2169w, 1581vs, 1434 m, 1385vs, 1278w, 1223m, 1138m, 740s, 715w.

[Co(L)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

4 was solvothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. A mixture of H2 L (0.5 mmol), NaN3 (1 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) in a aqueous ethanol (V:V = 1:1) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and heated to 120 °C for 48 h, the reaction vessel was cooled to room temperature over 12 h. Black−purple crystals were collected and washed sequentially by water and ethanol. Yield: ∼50% (based on H2 L)). Anal. Calcd. for C54H36Co6N12O12S6: C, 40.76; H, 2.28; N, 10.56. Found: C, 41.02; H, 2.49; N, 10.71%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 2360s, 2341m, 1565s, 1459s, 1434m, 1389vs, 1276s, 1234m, 1151s, 715vs, 733m, 653w.

For 4, the χm T value of 2.79 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K is much greater than the value (1.88 cm3 mol-1 K) of one isolated metal centers of CoII with S = 3/2 and g = 2.0, which is attributed to spin-orbital couplings. The high-temperature data (above 50 K) follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Curie constant C = 3.05 cm3 K mol-1 and negative Weiss constant θ = -34.49 K, in agreement with the overall antiferromagnetic interactions in the 3D network of 4 which is usually common in imidazole and syn-anti COO- bridges.
